subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Dialects
msgSnippet: Hi Tim It s the same for me. It is hard to distinguish, the short ah or on sound from the similar but longer aw sound in haul , as I speak with an
messageBody:
Hi Tim
It's the same for me. It is hard to distinguish, the short "ah" or "on" sound from
the similar but longer "aw" sound in "haul", as I speak with an American accent.
Actually I tend to use the "aw" letter a lot and restrict "on" to shorter vowel sounds
in-between 2 consonants. For example, Doc, hot, bottle, talk, rot and got.
 
As for the Schwa  sound, it is 90% of the time very very short.
I would mind having a letter for the longer soft "u" sound, but it is so rare, that
it doesn't cause a lot of confusion to lump the 2 sounds together under one
letter.
 
Regards, Paul V.
__________________________________________________________________
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
From: tim_rice09@...
Date: Sat, 6 Jan 2007 20:48:32 +0000
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Dialects

Well, the vowels for hawk and hock in my and many others speech are
one and the same. Though I still write them differently in
Quickscript. My dialect also has only one schwa sound, which was one
of the reasons I chose Quickscript over Shavian.
Despite its drawbacks, Quicksript is the best alternative to Orthodox
writing I have found so far.

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, pgabhart <pgabhart@.. .> wrote:
>
> Tim:
>
> I am curious, does your dialect distinguish between the vowels of
"hock"
> and "hawk"? Although I pronounce "on" with Awe as you would, I would
> use Ox for "hock." What phoneme would you use for what one does at a
> pawn shop?
>
> Paige
>
> tim_rice09 wrote:
> >
> > If the rules and spellings recommended in the Quickscript Manual are
> > to be disregarded, please, whatever you do, do not proclaim it the
> > standard. I am not accusing anyone of doing that but intend this to be
> > a warning to save Quickscript from what condemned Orthodox writing and
> > made many other reform alphabets unappealing.
> > The Senior contractions in the Manual save incalculable time and space
> > but take about a month to master, these I would like kept.
> > As for me I'll keep using the full alphabet, even though my dialect
> > (General American) uses only the Awe sound for the Ox letter it comes
> > in handy to distinguish say Walk from Wok. And has no Why sound.
> >
> >
>



Be one of the first to try Windows Live Mail.
